What is required as part of the IP application?

A. Submit only personal data and background information.
B. Complete an online application, provide personal data, background information, and answer short answer and essay questions. Additional requirements may include an interview, video question, audition, or resume submission.
C. Submit a resume and attend an audition only.
D. Fill out a paper application and mail it to the admissions office.

Should I apply for one semester or a year?

A. Always apply for one semester only and decide later if you want to extend.
B. Apply for a year if possible to secure your spot and visa, as extensions depend on space availability and visa regulations. Many students regret not staying the full academic year.
C. Apply for two semesters in different programs.
D. Apply for one semester and automatically receive an extension for a year.

Should I have other study abroad locations in mind when I apply?

A. No, students are always guaranteed their first-choice program.
B. Yes, because not all applicants can be accommodated in their first-choice program. Having multiple locations in mind and applying by the priority deadline increases your chances of admission.
C. No, you should only focus on your preferred program regardless of space constraints.
D. Yes, but only choose programs that don't require interviews or auditions.

Can I apply for more than one program?

A. No, students can only apply for one program per term.
B. Yes, students can apply for up to six programs and terms with one application. They will be considered for their preferences in order. Programs that require interviews or auditions are not available as alternate choices.
C. Yes, but only for programs that do not require a visa.
D. No, multiple applications will automatically be rejected.

When will I know whether or not I am accepted?

A. Decisions are released immediately after completing the application.
B. Applicants who apply by the priority deadline (September 23, 2024) will receive a decision on October 11, 2024. Those who apply after the priority deadline will be notified on a rolling basis, typically within 2-4 weeks, usually on Fridays.
C. All applicants are notified at the end of the application cycle.
D. Applicants must wait until the following semester to receive a decision.

Are there jobs for students while abroad?

A. No, student jobs are not available for those studying abroad.
B. Yes, many positions are available. IPRAs, media coordinators, and librarians are hired in Malibu before studying abroad. Additional positions may become available during the program, and program directors will reach out during the first month.
C. Yes, but only students in specific programs are eligible for jobs.
D. Yes, but jobs are only assigned after completing the program.

Why are priority applications due about a month after the beginning of the fall semester?

A. To ensure students complete their applications before midterms.
B. Because students need to register for prerequisite courses, including the first level of a language class (151), in early to mid-November. This timeline allows International Programs to review applications, give decisions, and allow students time to commit before registration.
C. To give International Programs enough time to process all applications before winter break.
D. To allow students to apply for multiple programs during the fall semester.

Who teaches the courses in International Programs?

A. The Pepperdine Program Director, the faculty-in-residence, and local faculty approved by academic divisional deans at the Malibu campus.
B. Only local faculty hired by the host country.
C. Only the Pepperdine Program Director.
D. Visiting faculty from other universities worldwide.

What does it mean if I was waitlisted for a program and what should I do?

A. It means the program could not accept all applicants due to space constraints or other factors. You must wait until the next application cycle.
B. It means you must contact the program director immediately to secure your spot.
C. It means the program could not accept all applicants due to space constraints or other factors. You can remain on the waitlist for a chance to be admitted later if space becomes available, or reapply for an alternate program still accepting applications.
D. It means your application was rejected, and you need to restart the process entirely.

What happens after I am accepted?

A. Students are automatically enrolled in their program without further steps.
B. Students must pay their program fees immediately to secure their spot.
C. Students must sign a legally binding IP contract to officially commit to their program and term. They should carefully review the contract, consult with family, healthcare providers, academic advisors, and financial aid advisors before signing. Financial penalties may apply if withdrawal occurs later. After signing, students should start preparing to go abroad.
D. Students should submit a new application to confirm their program choice.

Do Pepperdine's international programs have Monday-Friday classes?

A. The programs in Buenos Aires and Washington, D.C. have classes five days a week. European campus programs may have classes four or five days a week.
B. All international programs have classes five days a week.
C. All international programs have classes four days a week.
D. No international programs have Monday-Friday classes.

From where do the programs depart?

A. All programs require students to depart from Los Angeles International Airport (LAX).
B. Most programs allow students to choose their preferred departure location when booking their flight through Pepperdine's travel partner, Corniche Travel. However, some Faculty-led programs require students to join a group flight departing from and returning to LAX.
C. Students can book their flights independently from any airport.
D. Students must depart from Pepperdine's campus for all programs.

Can I arrange my own travel to the program?

A. Yes, students are free to arrange their own travel as long as they arrive on time.
B. No, students are required to book through Pepperdine's travel partner, Corniche Travel, as part of the flight policies agreed upon when signing the contract.
C. No, all travel must be arranged by the program director.
D. Yes, but only for domestic programs.

What opportunities are there for travel?

A. Students can travel to selected destinations as part of their educational experience, but academic responsibilities take priority. Each academic year program includes an educational field trip during the fall and spring terms. Students are also encouraged to explore the city and country where their program is located.
B. Students are allowed unlimited travel during the program without restrictions.
C. Students are only allowed to travel during designated breaks, with no educational trips included.
D. Students must remain within the host city for the duration of the program.

I'm going overseas for a year. What do I do over the winter break?

A. Students can stay on campus during winter break but must pay an additional fee.
B. Students must move out completely during winter break, including removing their belongings from their rooms.
C. Students cannot stay on campuses during winter break as Pepperdine campuses close. Students in a homestay can inquire about staying with their host family, though it is not guaranteed. Students studying abroad for the full academic year may leave their belongings in their rooms but will not have access to them until the campus reopens.
D. Students can access their belongings during the break but cannot stay overnight on campus.

Is there any support for returning students who are struggling with being back in Malibu?

A. No, students are expected to adjust on their own without formal support.
B. Yes, the Landed chapel series supports students returning for the spring semester, helping them process the transition and evaluate how they've changed. Landed events are also held in the fall for students returning from the spring semester or academic year.
C. Yes, but only informal peer support groups are available.
D. No, but counseling services are offered for a fee.

How can I get involved after returning from my program?

A. Participate in "The Return" event at the beginning of the year to celebrate your time abroad and share experiences with the new freshmen class. Alumni can also help with events and orientations by partnering with the program ambassador.
B. Return to your program location as a student mentor for new participants.
C. Enroll in a special class for program alumni to continue learning about global cultures.
D. Plan a reunion trip with fellow alumni to revisit the program location.

What are the withdrawal fees if I decide to break my contract?

A. There are no fees for withdrawing as long as you notify the International Programs Office.
B. Withdrawal fees depend on the term for which you signed your contract and the date of your withdrawal. Details can be found in your contract and by contacting the International Programs Office at 310.506.4230 or international.programs@pepperdine.edu.
C. The fee is a flat rate for all withdrawals, regardless of the term or withdrawal date.
D. There are no fees if you withdraw at least 30 days before the start of your program.

Do I need any vaccinations to study abroad?

A. No vaccinations are required for any study abroad program.
B. It depends on the program and destination. Some countries require specific vaccinations, while others recommend them. Students are responsible for getting information about necessary vaccinations and can contact International SOS at (215) 942-8226 or consult the CDC website for guidance.
C. Yes, Pepperdine requires all students to be vaccinated against common diseases before studying abroad.
D. Vaccinations are optional and entirely up to the student's discretion.

Can I only study abroad sophomore year?

A. No, students from any year who meet the admissions requirements and prerequisites can apply for programs that are accepting new applications. Abroad locations offer courses during the fall, spring, and summer terms, so plan with your academic advisor to ensure your study abroad plans align with your graduation goals.
B. Yes, studying abroad is restricted to sophomore year only.
C. No, but only summer sessions are available to students outside their sophomore year.
D. Yes, but exceptions may be made for students with outstanding academic achievements.

If I didn't apply by the IP Priority Deadline, can I still apply?

A. No, applications are closed after the priority deadline.
B. Yes, many programs still accept applications on a rolling basis after the priority deadline, but some may stop accepting new applications. Check the programs page for a list of open programs and apply as soon as possible to secure your spot.
C. No, but you can request an exception from the International Programs Office.
D. Yes, but only for summer term programs.

Do I travel on every weekend while abroad?

A. Yes, students are required to travel every weekend to fully experience the culture.
B. No, it's up to you! You can travel as much or as little as you like, but remember to explore your host country and immerse yourself in the local culture. Traveling every weekend can be exhausting, and you might miss out on valuable experiences where you're studying.
C. Yes, traveling every weekend is included in the program itinerary.
D. No, students are restricted from traveling outside the host country during weekends.

Should I get a smartphone that works abroad?

A. No, students can rely on Wi-Fi and public phones for communication.
B. No, students are provided with phones by the program upon arrival.
C. Yes, students are required to have a smartphone with an international calling and data plan to use International SOS applications and for emergency contact. Program locations also provide suggestions for securing a local phone and SIM card upon arrival.
D. Yes, but only for students attending programs in remote locations.

What is the Tyler Campus Center and where is it?

A. The Tyler Campus Center is a classroom building located next to the library.
B. The Tyler Campus Center is the focal point for undergraduate social life and co-curricular activity. It houses the bookstore, dining facilities, the Light House, the Hub for Spiritual Life, International Programs, and Student Affairs offices. It can be accessed from Joslyn Plaza, Adamson Plaza, or the Amphitheatre area.
C. The Tyler Campus Center is a residence hall for first-year students, located on the south side of campus.
D. The Tyler Campus Center is exclusively for administrative offices and is not open to students.

What is the Pendleton Learning Center (PLC) and where is it?

A. The PLC is a recreational center for students located near the dormitories.
B. The PLC houses separate study rooms for Payson Library, classrooms, offices, and one of Seaver College's largest lecture halls.
C. The PLC is a student dining facility located next to Payson Library.
D. The PLC is exclusively a faculty office building located on the edge of campus.

What is the Thornton Administrative Center and where is it?

A. TAC is a student center located next to the library, offering dining and recreational facilities.
B. TAC is a residential building for faculty members, located near the campus perimeter.
C. TAC houses University administrative offices, admissions, fundraising offices, Seaver College's dean's office, and historical displays of founder George Pepperdine and namesake Blanche Seaver. It is the first building visitors encounter after entering the main gate, with visitor parking available in front of the building, behind it (token required), or on adjacent streets.
D. TAC is a large lecture hall used exclusively for business and economics classes, located at the campus center.

What is the Rockwell Academic Center and where is it?

A. The Rockwell Academic Center is a student union building located next to Payson Library.
B. The Rockwell Academic Center houses classrooms, laboratories, and faculty offices for the Natural Science Division.
C. The Rockwell Academic Center is a residential facility for science students located near the dormitories.
D. The Rockwell Academic Center is an administrative building focused on admissions and financial aid services.

What is the Keck Science Center and where is it?

A. The Keck Science Center houses the Natural Science Division, including classrooms, laboratories, and faculty offices. It is accessible via a service road at the top of the stairway leading to Firestone Fieldhouse, with internal connecting access through the Appleby Center (to KSC 4th floor) and Rockwell Academic Center (to KSC 3rd floor).
B. The Keck Science Center is a residence hall for science students, located near the Firestone Fieldhouse.
C. The Keck Science Center is a library annex for the Natural Science Division, located next to Rockwell Academic Center.
D. The Keck Science Center is a recreational facility for science majors, located in the lower campus area.

What is the Appleby Center and where is it?

A. The Appleby Center is a library for the Social Science and Religion Divisions, located near the Keck Science Center.
B. The Appleby Center houses the offices for the Social Science and Religion Divisions, as well as classrooms and faculty offices. It is accessible from the Seaver Main Parking Lot, adjacent to the Weisman Museum, with internal connecting access through the Rockwell Academic Center and Keck Science Center.
C. The Appleby Center is a residential hall for students majoring in social sciences and religion, located on lower campus.
D. The Appleby Center is a dining facility for social sciences and religion students, located near Firestone Fieldhouse.

What is the Elkins Auditorium and where is it?

A. The Elkins Auditorium is the University's largest lecture hall on the Seaver campus, located on the north side of Joslyn Plaza. It is accessible via Joslyn Plaza, adjacent to the Rockwell Academic Center, Black Family Plaza Classrooms, and the fountain, with internal connecting access via the Plaza Classrooms and Rockwell Academic Center.
B. The Elkins Auditorium is a performing arts theater located near the Weisman Museum.
C. The Elkins Auditorium is a small seminar room for graduate students, located within the Black Family Plaza Classrooms.
D. The Elkins Auditorium is a dining facility for large student gatherings, located on the lower campus.

What is the Cultural Arts Center and where is it?

A. The Cultural Arts Center is a large concert hall for major performances, located next to the Seaver Main Parking Lot.
B. The Cultural Arts Center is a residence hall for students in Fine Arts and Humanities majors, located near Smothers Theatre.
C. The Cultural Arts Center is home to the Fine Arts Division and the Humanities and Teacher Preparation Division offices. It contains classrooms, faculty offices, art studios, and smaller performance venues. It is accessible via the Seaver Main Parking Lot walkway alongside the Weisman Museum and Smothers Theatre, with internal connecting access to Smothers Theatre.
D. The Cultural Arts Center is a library for Fine Arts and Humanities students, located adjacent to the Weisman Museum.

What is Smothers Theatre and where is it?

A. Smothers Theatre is a lecture hall used for large academic classes, located near the Seaver Main Parking Lot.
B. Smothers Theatre is the primary performance space of the Center for the Arts and the only professional performing arts center in Malibu. It hosts student theatrical productions, musical performances, and national tours of major performers. It also houses the business and box offices of the Center for the Arts. Access is available from the Main Seaver Parking Lot, with internal connecting access through the Ahmanson Music Building and Cultural Arts Center.
C. Smothers Theatre is a rehearsal space for student music majors, located inside the Ahmanson Music Building.
D. Smothers Theatre is a student union building for fine arts majors, located next to the Cultural Arts Center.

What is Firestone Fieldhouse and where is it?

A. Firestone Fieldhouse is a recreational center for intramural sports, located next to Joslyn Plaza.
B. Firestone Fieldhouse is a small auditorium used for academic lectures, located off Banowsky Boulevard.
C. Firestone Fieldhouse is the primary athletic facility on the Malibu campus, home to the award-winning Waves basketball and volleyball teams. It serves as the largest indoor assembly venue on campus, seating 5,000, and is also used for Wednesday chapel meetings. The Weight Center is located in the basement, and the athletics department offices are on the second floor. Access is via John Tyler Drive, with adjacent parking to the south, and pedestrian access includes stairs from Joslyn Plaza or partial elevator access through the Keck Science Center.
D. Firestone Fieldhouse is an outdoor stadium for track and field events, located at the north edge of campus.

What is the Center for Communication and Business and where is it?

A. The CCB is a recreational space for communication and business students, located near the Seaver Main Parking Lot.
B. The CCB houses the academic divisions of Communication and Business, along with classrooms, offices, a live-feed broadcast studio, and Pepperdine's TV station, NewsWaves, which broadcasts to over 13,000 people in Malibu and Calabasas. It also contains the headquarters for the Department of Public Safety. Access is via Seaver Drive, with restricted parking in the CCB Parking Lot (card key required).
C. The CCB is a performing arts building for media productions, located near Joslyn Plaza.
D. The CCB is a student residence hall for business and communication majors, located on the south side of campus.

What is Payson Library and where is it? 

A. Payson Library is the primary library facility on the Malibu campus and the headquarters of the Pepperdine Libraries, serving students both online and at remote campuses. It contains book stacks, periodicals, audio/visual materials, special collections, University archives, reading areas, study carrels, computer labs, group study areas, photocopiers, library offices, and the Kresge Reading Room.
B. Payson Library is a small departmental library specifically for history majors, located near Joslyn Plaza.
C. Payson Library is a residence hall for students pursuing library science, located near Firestone Fieldhouse.
D. Payson Library is a bookstore for students, providing access to textbooks and academic supplies.

What is Stauffer Chapel and where is it? 

A. Stauffer Chapel is a student lounge for relaxation and study, located near the Amphitheatre.
B. Stauffer Chapel serves as a focal point for worship, prayer, and meditation on the Seaver Campus. It is also used for meetings, lectures, musical performances, and special events. Access is available via the Chapel Parking Lot (card key required), stairways and paved walkways from Banowsky Blvd., or the service road below Tyler Campus Center. It is located at the foot of the stairs leading down from the Amphitheatre.
C. Stauffer Chapel is a classroom building for theology courses, located next to Banowsky Blvd.
D. Stauffer Chapel is a recreational facility for hosting small gatherings, located near Tyler Campus Center.

How can I apply to speak at the ceremony?

A. Any student may apply to speak at the ceremony, regardless of their graduation status.
B. Graduating seniors of 2024 may apply to speak at commencement but must pass an audition process.
C. Graduating seniors of 2024 may apply to speak at commencement. Two roles are available: Graduation Speaker and Graduate to lead the Pledge of Allegiance. Additional information can be found on the Senior Speaker page.
D. Only students nominated by faculty are eligible to apply for speaking roles at the ceremony.

Will the ceremony be broadcast for those unable to attend?

A. Yes, all in-person activities will be broadcast online, live, and on-demand for future viewing. The link will be available on the commencement website, and livestreams will begin 15 minutes prior to the start of each ceremony.
B. No, the ceremony will not be broadcast, but a recording will be made available after the event.
C. Yes, the ceremony will only be livestreamed with no option for on-demand viewing.
D. No, there are no online options for viewing the ceremony.

Do I need to attend the in-person commencement ceremony at Alumni Park to have my degree conferred?

A. No, graduates do not need to attend the in-person ceremony to have their degree conferred. Diplomas will be mailed to the address on file approximately 120 days after graduation. Ensure your address is updated with OneStop. If you prefer to pick up your diploma, contact OneStop.
B. Yes, attendance at the in-person ceremony is mandatory to have your degree conferred.
C. Yes, but exceptions are made for students with extenuating circumstances.
D. No, graduates must pick up their diploma on campus after the ceremony.

Will there be accessible parking and shuttles?

A. No, accessible parking and shuttles will not be available during the event.
B. Yes, all parking is reserved for guests with accessibility needs, and shuttles are available on a limited schedule.
C. Yes, accessible parking is available in the Firestone Fieldhouse parking lot (Parking Lot P) on a first-come, first-serve basis. Shuttles will be in service and accessible at marked campus shuttle stops. Carpooling is recommended due to potential traffic delays and limited parking.
D. No, guests with accessibility needs must arrange for private transportation to the event.

Do I need to order or reserve regalia?

A. No, regalia will be provided to all graduates at the ceremony without prior reservation.
B. No, regalia is not required to attend the ceremony.
C. Yes, graduates attending the ceremony in person must reserve their regalia online through Herff Jones' website. In-person assistance is available during Graduation Kickoff at the Malibu campus bookstore on Tuesday, February 13, and Wednesday, February 14, from 10 AM to 4 PM.
D. Yes, but graduates must purchase regalia directly at the bookstore without any online reservation options.

How do graduates get honor cords?

A. Honor cords are given to undergraduate students with a minimum 3.5 GPA. Eligible students will be contacted by their school's commencement coordinator or academic advisor during the spring semester. Honor cords are free of charge.
B. Honor cords are available for purchase at the campus bookstore for any student interested in receiving one.
C. Honor cords are only given to graduate students who meet their program's specific requirements.
D. Honor cords are awarded to all students attending the commencement ceremony, regardless of GPA.

Where do I pick up my honor cord?

A. Honor cords will be mailed to eligible students before the ceremony.
B. Honor cords can be picked up prior to the commencement ceremony at the Graduate Check-In area. Honors students should arrive at Alumni Park at 9 AM on the morning of the ceremony.
C. Honor cords will be distributed during the commencement ceremony on stage.
D. Honor cords must be picked up from the campus bookstore the day before the ceremony.

When will I get my diploma?

A. Diplomas will be distributed during the commencement ceremony.
B. Diplomas will be mailed to the diploma address on file approximately 120 days after degrees are conferred on April 27. Ensure your address is updated with OneStop. If you prefer to pick up your diploma, contact OneStop.
C. Diplomas will be available for pickup on campus 30 days after the ceremony.
D. Diplomas will be emailed as digital files immediately after the degree is conferred.

What if I have pending financial obligations?

A. Pending financial obligations can be resolved after graduation without any penalties.
B. Clear all financial obligations with the Library, Student Health Center, Student Accounts Office, and Financial Aid Office before graduation. Additionally, if you borrowed Federal Direct Stafford, Federal Perkins, or Pepperdine Institutional loans, complete an online Loan Exit Counseling session before graduation. For Student Accounts information, call 310.506.8000, and visit the Federal Direct Loan Exit Counseling Information webpage for further details.
C. You only need to resolve obligations with the Financial Aid Office before graduation.
D. Financial obligations are automatically cleared after the degree is conferred.

Can I rent regalia on the day of my commencement ceremony?

A. No, regalia cannot be rented on the day of the ceremony and must be picked up in advance.
B. Yes, a limited amount of regalia will be available at Alumni Park on the day of the ceremony, but to avoid waiting in long lines, it is strongly recommended to pick up your regalia at Grad Fest on the Malibu Campus at Mullin Town Square.
C. Yes, but regalia rented on the day of the ceremony will incur an extra fee.
D. No, regalia is only available for purchase, not rental, before the ceremony.

Will I be able to invite guests to attend? How do I sign up to attend the in-person commencement ceremonies at Alumni Park?

A. Yes, Seaver College's Commencement Ceremony at Alumni Park is open to all guests of graduating students. In the unlikely event of inclement weather requiring a change of venue, this policy may change. Graduates are encouraged to check the Seaver graduation webpage frequently for updates.
B. No, attendance is restricted to immediate family members only.
C. Yes, but each graduate is limited to a maximum of two guests.
D. No, the ceremony is exclusively for graduating students and faculty members.

How do I apply for graduation? 

A. Log in to WaveNet and navigate to the "Other Academic" drop-down menu. Select "Apply for Graduation" and submit your intent. Confirm your major, indicate your ceremony attendance, update your diploma mailing address, and update your diploma name if necessary. Consult your Academic Advising Associate for questions about graduation requirements, and regularly check your Pepperdine email for updates from the graduation office.
B. Complete a paper application available at the Registrar's Office and mail it to the graduation office.
C. Email your Academic Advising Associate directly with your graduation intent and provide your diploma mailing address.
D. Fill out a form at the commencement rehearsal to finalize your graduation application.

How do I add a class by number?

A. Go to the "Class Registration" section, enter the catalog number, and click "Add Class."
B. Click the "Class Search" link under the Shopping Cart, enter the class number in the "Enter Class Nbr." box, and click "Enter." Then, click "Next" to add the class to your cart. Once all classes are selected, click "Add/Submit/Edit," validate, and enroll by clicking "Finish Enrolling."
C. Search for the course by title and click "Add to Cart" from the search results.
D. Click the "Course Registration" link, enter the course code, and automatically add it to your schedule without needing to validate.

How do I add a class by search?

A. Enter the class number in the "Add Class" section and click "Submit."
B. Click the "Class Search" link under the Shopping Cart, enter search criteria by Subject or course number, and click "Search." Select the class you wish to add, click "Next" to add it to your shopping cart, and then proceed to enroll by clicking "Finish Enrolling."
C. Use the "Quick Add" feature by entering the course name and automatically adding it to your schedule.
D. Search for courses by department and manually add them to your cart from the course catalog without validating.

How do I drop a class?

A. In the Home view, select a term, and click the "Drop All Classes" button.
C. In the Home view, select a term, click the "Drop" button, then select the classes you wish to drop by checking the boxes next to them. Click "Drop Selected Classes," review your selections, and click "Finish Dropping" to complete the process.
B. Go to the "Course Registration" section, find the class you want to drop, and click "Remove."
D. In the Student Center, select the class and click "Remove from Schedule" directly from the class list.

How do I view my finances on my student account?

A. Log in to WaveNet, click on the "Student" tab, then click the "Finances" icon. The next page will display all your financial services. To check account activity, scroll down to "Account Activity" and adjust the date range or select a term to view activity.
B. Log in to WaveNet and go to the "Financial Aid" section to view your account balance.
C. Click on the "Student Services" tab and select "View Finances" to access your account activity.
D. Go to the "Account Settings" section in WaveNet and select "Financial Overview" to view your financial history.

How do I view my financial aid? 

A. Log in to WaveNet, click on the "Student" tab, then click the "Finances" icon. Select "View Financial Aid Status" and choose the aid year to see your awards summary. If needed, use the "Accept/Decline Awards" button to manage your awards.
B. Log in to WaveNet and go to the "Financial Aid" section to directly view your aid status without selecting an academic year.
C. Go to the "Student Services" tab and click on "View Financial Aid" to access your awards summary and accept or decline them.
D. Navigate to the "Account Settings" and select "Financial Aid Overview" to review your awards and manage acceptance.

How do I make a payment?

A. Log in to WaveNet, click on the "Student" tab, access "Finances," and select "View Account Summary." Then click "Make a Payment" and follow the on-screen instructions to complete your payment.
B. Log in to WaveNet, click on the "Student" tab, then select "Make a Payment" directly from the home page. Follow the instructions to complete the payment.
C. In WaveNet, go to the "Student Services" tab, click "Financial Aid," and make a payment directly from there.
D. Log in to WaveNet, go to "Student Account Settings," and select "Payment Options" to complete the transaction.

How do I enroll in e Refund?

How do I enroll in eRefund in WaveNet?

B. Log in to WaveNet, go to the "Financial Aid" tab, and select the "eRefund" option to enter your bank details for direct deposit.

D. Log in to WaveNet, click the "eRefund" link in the "Student Services" tab, and follow the instructions to set up your refund preference.

How do I access my degree progress?

B. Go to the "Student Services" tab, click on "Degree Progress," and select the "View Degree Report" option.
C. Log in to WaveNet, go to the "Financial Aid" tab, and select "Degree Progress" to view your report.
D. From the "Student" tab, click on "My Classes" and then "Degree Requirements" to view your audit.

How do I check my grades?

B. Go to the "Student Services" tab and select "My Grades" to view your academic progress.
C. Click on the "Course Registration" tab to see your current and past grades.

How do I view my class schedule?

B. Go to the "Student Services" tab, select "My Classes," and choose the "Class Schedule" option.

How do I view registration and account holds?

How do I view or contact my advisor?

How do I drop a class on mobile?

How do I invite a guest on wavenet?

B. Go to the "Student Services" tab, select "Guest Invitations," and email the invitation directly to the guest.

D. Navigate to the "Financial Aid" section, click "Invite Guest," and provide the guest's email address.

How does a invited Wavenet guest receive their invitation?

A. The student sends a physical invitation that includes the guest's account credentials.
B. The guest receives a phone call with a link to set up their account.
C. The guest receives an email invitation with a link to the Guest Access Account Creation page, where they can begin the account setup process.
D. The student must give the guest a unique access code to enter directly into WaveNet.

How does an invited Wavenet guest create their account?

A. The guest logs into WaveNet using the link in the invitation email and enters their personal information to set up their account.
B. The guest will be prompted to create a username and password in the email and log in directly to WaveNet.

How does a Wavenet guest use the guest access center?

A. After creating an account, the guest logs into WaveNet, selects the "Student Services" tab, and accesses the "Guest Access" section.
B. Once the guest has created an account, they log into WaveNet, click the "Guest Access Center" link under the "Guest" tab, and navigate the available options based on the permissions set by the student, such as viewing schedules or financial aid.
C. The guest must wait for an email with a link to the Guest Access Center after logging in.
D. The guest logs into WaveNet, goes to the "Guest Access" tab, and can directly make payments or access course schedules.

What should a Wavenet guest do if they have forgotten their login information?

A. Reset the password through the "Forgot Password" link on the login page.
B. Contact Tech Central at 310.506.4357 (HELP) for assistance.

Can I change the access the guest has to certain features on Wavenet?

How do I help mutiple students as a guest?

Do I have to remove guest access when I graduate?

Explain the steps of the class registration process. 

A. Review your degree audit report (DAR), build a course schedule, select alternate course options, clear any registration holds, add/drop classes during the registration period, and view your new schedule.
B. Complete the application for graduation, clear any holds, and view your course schedule.
C. Build a course schedule, select courses from the catalog, and register without reviewing your degree audit report (DAR).
D. Review your grades from the previous semester, choose alternate courses, and automatically enroll in courses without adding any holds.

How do I use the Wavenet wishlist?

A. Log in to WaveNet, click on "Student Services," then select "Wishlist." Pick the appropriate term and search for classes. Add selected classes to your wishlist, and when your registration time comes, you can select classes from the wishlist to register.

C. Use the "Course Catalog" to select courses and automatically add them to your wishlist, ensuring your registration is completed automatically.

How do I view my DAR? 

A. Log in to WaveNet, go to the "Student Services" tab, and select the "Degree Audit" link in the Student Records area.
B. Log in to WaveNet, click on "My Classes," and select the "View Degree Audit" option from the dropdown menu.
C. Log in to WaveNet, go to the "Academics" tab, and select "Degree Progress" to view your DAR.
D. Log in to WaveNet, click on "Student Services," and select "Academic History" to access your Degree Audit.

How do I become eligible for the Dean's List?

A. Complete at least twelve letter-graded units, receive no grade below a "C," have a GPA of at least 3.0, and be in the top 25 percent of the class.
B. Complete at least twelve letter-graded units, receive no grade below a "C," have no grades of "I" or "NC," be in the top 10 percent of the class, and have a term GPA of at least 3.5.
C. Complete at least eight units, receive no grades below "B," and maintain a GPA of 3.0.
D. Complete at least twelve units, have a GPA of at least 3.0, and receive no grades below "B" during the semester.

How do I document an incomplete?

A. Students must email their instructor and academic advisor to request an incomplete and submit a form to the Divisional Dean for approval.
B. The student must start the request in Etrieve by completing the Incomplete Course Agreement Form after discussing the situation with the instructor. The form is then routed through the Director of Academic Advising, the instructor, and the Divisional Dean for approval before being finalized in the student's file.
C. The student must submit a request to the Dean's Office, who will then approve or deny the incomplete without further steps.
D. Students must call their instructor to explain the situation and then complete a form to be sent directly to the Registrar for processing.

How do I request my transcript?

A. Complete a Transcript Order Form and return it by mail with cash, check, or money order for $10.00 per copy.
B. Order your transcript by completing the Transcript Order Form and mailing it to Pepperdine University with payment by cash, check, or money order. Alternatively, you can order online via the National Student Clearinghouse for $10.00 per copy.
C. Contact the Registrar's Office by phone or email to request your transcript.
D. Submit your transcript request through your WaveNet account with no charge or payment required.

What is the grade dispute process? 

A. The process starts by submitting a written appeal to the division dean with a copy to the instructor, followed by assembling relevant class materials. If unresolved, an ad hoc committee evaluates the case and the division dean makes the final decision.
B. The student must first discuss the issue privately with the instructor. If the dispute is not resolved, the student submits a written appeal to the division dean, gathers relevant materials, and the instructor submits their documents. An ad hoc committee evaluates the case and the division dean makes the final decision.
C. The student submits an online form to the Registrar's Office, and the grade dispute is resolved by the Associate Dean without the need for a committee.
D. The student must directly appeal to the academic dean without involving the instructor or division dean, and a decision is made by the dean's office based on the student's case.

How do I apply to graduate?

A. Log in to WaveNet, go to the "Student Services" tab, and select "Apply for Graduation" to submit your intent, verify your major, choose whether you plan to attend the ceremony, and update your diploma name and mailing address.
B. Log in to WaveNet, select "Other Academic" from the drop-down menu, and click the "Apply for Graduation" link. Verify your major, select your diploma mailing address, update your name if necessary, and contact your Academic Advising Associate if you have any questions about remaining requirements.
C. Log in to WaveNet, go to the "Graduation" tab, and submit your application for graduation, including diploma name and address updates.
D. Navigate to the "Student Services" tab, click on "Apply for Graduation," and email the Registrar's Office with your graduation request.

How do I get on campus housing as a first year student? 

A. First-year students are automatically assigned housing when they are admitted and do not need to submit a housing application.
B. Newly admitted students for the 2024-2025 academic year follow a separate process. They should visit the first-year housing web page for more details and submit their housing application in June.

What on-campus parking areas may I utilize if I have an FY - First Year parking permit?

What do I do in the event of a crime?

What are the requirements of an orientation leader?

A. Must have a GPA of 2.5 or above and be in good standing with the university. Must also be available for training and orientation in the spring semester.
B. Must have a GPA of 2.0 or above, be in good standing with the university, study on the Malibu campus for the fall semester, and be available for all training and New Student Orientation dates in August.

What are the duties of an orientation leader?

A. Help new students move into on-campus housing, answer questions from students and parents, lead small group activities, keep the orientation schedule running smoothly, and support the NSO team with other duties as needed.
B. Lead large group lectures, assist with student academic advising, and handle all student housing assignments.

How do I apply to be an orientation coordinator?

How do I get mental health counseling?

What requirements are there to apply for an IP program? 

A. Applicants must have a GPA of at least 3.0, have completed one full-time semester at Seaver College, and agree to comply with the IP's COVID-19 vaccine policy.
B. Applicants must be a current Seaver College student in good standing, have completed one full-time semester at Seaver College, have at least a 2.5 GPA, and agree to comply with the IP's COVID-19 vaccine policy.
C. Applicants must be enrolled in a graduate program, have a GPA of 3.5 or higher, and be nominated by a faculty member.
D. Applicants must have completed two full-time semesters at Seaver College, have a GPA of at least 3.0, and do not need to comply with any vaccine policy.

How do I apply for an international program? 

A. Use the "Apply" button on the IP website or sign in to WaveNet and click "IP Apps Sum '25 thru Spr '26" under "Popular Links." Complete the intake questions, select your program and term, fill out the application, and submit it by the deadline.
B. Submit a paper application to the Student Affairs Office and wait for approval.
C. Email the International Programs office to request an application, then schedule an interview to finalize your application.
D. Apply directly through the Housing Office by selecting your preferred program and term, and submit your application via email.

How should I prepare for an IP interview?

A. Dress casually, be late to the interview, and try to answer the questions quickly without much thought.
B. Treat it like a job interview: dress nicely, arrive on time, and think about your answers to questions like why you applied, what you hope to gain, and how you will manage challenges abroad.
C. Wear your school uniform and be prepared to answer only about your academic achievements.
D. Focus on providing short, simple answers to questions and do not elaborate on your personal experiences.

How do I apply for an IP scholarship?

B. Start your IP application through the ViaTRM portal, and you will automatically receive instructions and an optional form to apply for the IP Scholarship.
C. Contact the Student Affairs Office for a scholarship form and submit it to the Financial Aid Office.
D. Apply through the Student Services portal, and the scholarship form will be sent to you after submitting your academic transcripts.

How does International Programs make admissions decisions?

A. Admissions decisions are based solely on GPA and interview performance.
B. The IP Selection Committee only considers GPA and the completion of application materials, without looking at campus citizenship.
C. Admissions decisions are made based only on essay responses and interview outcomes.
D. The IP Selection Committee makes decisions based on GPA, campus citizenship, essays, application information, interview, supplemental materials, and certain degree requirements.

How do I get a passport?

A. Students do not need a passport if they are traveling to Washington, D.C. or other U.S. domestic locations.
B. All students studying abroad must have a valid passport, which should be valid for at least 6 months past their return date. Students should start the process of applying for or renewing their passport immediately and refer to the U.S. Department of State's Passport Services website for more information.
C. Students can only obtain a passport after they are admitted to the program and are not required to renew it.
D. Passport applications are only available through the Student Services Office and are processed after students have received their visa.

How do I extend my stay overseas and what are flight implications?

A. Students can extend their flight at the time of booking or contact Corniche Travel for adjustments. They are responsible for any associated fees and must ensure that changes do not affect their immigration status.
B. Students must rebook their flight through the Housing Office, and no additional fees will apply for extending the stay.
C. Students can request to extend their flight after booking, but they cannot change their departure date or route. They must also ensure they have the necessary insurance coverage for any additional travel days.
D. Students are not allowed to extend their stay overseas and must return on the scheduled flight date.

Why isn't Pepperdine wifi letting me connect/how do I disable MAC randomization?

A. Wi-Fi issues are caused by outdated routers; restart your router to fix the problem.

D. To fix Wi-Fi connectivity, you need to reset your password in the WaveNet portal.

D. Wait for a few hours as Wi-Fi issues typically resolve themselves automatically.
